The Witten genus is surjective at p=3

Jul 18, 2019

In this post, I described a spectrum ; this is defined to be the Thom spectrum of a map , where sits in a fiber sequence . There is a ring map , and the claim we’d like to prove is that this composite is a surjection. I’ll sketch a proof of this after -completion.

Recall that the homotopy groups of -complete are given by a quotient of , where and come from the sphere. To show surjectivity of the map , we need to find lifts of all these generators. Clearly and live in ; we need to next lift and .

For this, note that the -skeleton of is (by construction) , so the map given by gives the desired element . Similarly, the -skeleton of is , and the map given by and (not so sure about this last one) gives the desired element .

We now need to realize , , and in . Let’s first see how one could obtain these elements in , if all we knew was the -homology of , and that vanishes in . First, since , we would obtain a map extending . Upon taking -homology, we obtain a map . Recall that , where the degree of a generator is twice its subscript. This contains , which is some polynomial in the s. The generator maps to (in the ANSS, this translates to the fact that there’s a off hitting ). Therefore, the composite (where the first map comes from the -torsionness of ) detects the element .

How do we get and ? As the names of the elements suggest, we use the multiplication on . Namely, let denote the Thom spectrum of the composite ; for instance, , , and . The multiplication on defines maps . Since, when , the generator in -homology in dimension maps to , we find that for general , the generator in -homology in dimension is mapped by to . Now, one can see from the cell structure of these s that there are maps and (note that , so this final map comes from the unit of ), and their images in are and .

This suggests a plan for proving that , , and live in : namely, we first show that lives in , prove that vanishes in , and calculate that the map sends the generator in dimension to . (Note that if the map is injective, then this final statement is a consequence of the analogous statement for .) The vanishing of is in fact a consequence of the existence of in the ANSS, by an argument that is already used for : we know by Toda that vanishes in the sphere, so it must vanish in . For , we find that the ANSS only allows for one differential to kill this element: it’s a emanating from . By multiplicativity, we find that . The upshot of this discussion is that we therefore need to calculate through dimension , as well as the ANSS for through that dimension, and show that there is only one possibility for the differential killing .

For this plan to work, we need to calculate . First note that , where . Using this, we find that does indeed live in , via the same formulae (see, e.g., Figure 1 here) used to define in . By the discussion in the last two paragraphs, we find that the ring map hits all polynomial generators in the target, so is surjective. We conclude that the Witten genus is surjective upon -completion.

Presumably a similar proof could give the result at , and then we’d have the surjectivity of the integral Witten genus by an arithmetic fracture square. The homotopy of is a lot more busy at , though, so I haven’t tried to worked this out yet.

Added later: I talked with Mark Behrens about this, and he told me that my proof for surjectivity of seems right. Moreover, after talking with him, I think the same method of proof as above would work to show that the appropriate multiples of powers of actually live in (so we’re at the prime ), where we instead use instead of . At , we have a -differential, given by (which arises because must be killed, since vanishes in , where is represented by ), and so arguing as above, we get a map which sends the generator in degree in -homology to , and for which the map detects . We can then run a similar argument as the one given above (with some additional doable calculational material which we need to fill in). Now, we can conclude using Proposition 4.6 here (which, unlike the sought-after Theorem 6.25 in that paper, is actually a published computation) that the map is surjective, and hence that the Witten genus, when thought of as landing in the ring of modular forms, is surjective. This does not prove that the ABGHR orientation is surjective on homotopy — that’s a much stronger statement. I believe that it’s true, but a lot more work would be required to prove it.
